From the given electric field, we can also calculate the magnetic field, $\vec{B}$, as follows:

$\vec{B}=\frac{E_{0}}{c} \sin \left(k z-\omega t\right) \hat{v}$, where $\hat{v}$ is the unit vector in the direction of the magnetic field.

From the given electric field, we can calculate the unit vector in the direction of the magnetic field, $\hat{v}$, as follows:

$\hat{v}=\frac{\vec{E} \times \hat{k}}{|\vec{E} \times \hat{k}|}=\frac{30 \left(2 \hat{x}+\hat{y}\right) \times \hat{k}}{|30 \left(2 \hat{x}+\hat{y}\right) \times \hat{k}|}=\frac{30 \left(-\hat{y}+2 \hat{z}\right)}{\sqrt{30^{2} \left(2^{2}+1^{2}\right)}}=\frac{-\hat{y}+2 \hat{z}}{\sqrt{13}}$

Therefore, the magnetic field associated with the given electric field is given by:

$\vec{B}=\frac{E_{0}}{c} \sin \left(k z-\omega t\right) \hat{v}=\frac{30 \mathrm{Vm}^{-1}}{3 \times 10^{8} \mathrm{m} \mathrm{s}^{-1}} \sin \left[2 \pi\left(5 \times 10^{14} t-\frac{10^{7}}{3} z\right)\right] \left(-\hat{y}+2 \hat{z}\right)$

From the above equation, we can calculate the components of the magnetic field as follows:

$B_{x}=-\frac{30 \mathrm{Vm}^{-1}}{3 \times 10^{8} \mathrm{m} \mathrm{s}^{-1}} \sin \left[2 \pi\left(5 \times 10^{14} t-\frac{10^{7}}{3} z\right)\right]$

$B_{y}=2 \times \frac{30 \mathrm{Vm}^{-1}}{3 \times 10^{8} \mathrm{m} \mathrm{s}^{-1}} \sin \left[2 \pi\left(5 \times 10^{14} t-\frac{10^{7}}{3} z\right)\right]$

Therefore, the correct options are (A) and (B). The wave is not polarized in the $x y$-plane with polarization angle $30^{\circ}$ with respect to the $x$-axis, so option (C) is incorrect. The refractive index of the medium is not given, so option (D) is also incorrect.

The final answer is (A) and (B).

question: A string of length $1 \mathrm{~m}$ and mass $2 \times 10^{-5} \mathrm{~kg}$ is under tension $T$. When the string vibrates, two successive harmonics are found to occur at frequencies $750 \mathrm{~Hz}$ and $1000 \mathrm{~Hz}$. What is the value of tension $T$ in Newton?
prompt:
In this problem, the final answer will be a non-negative integer. Give a detailed solution and end the solution with the final answer.

Problem: A string of length $1 \mathrm{~m}$ and mass $2 \times 10^{-5} \mathrm{~kg}$ is under tension $T$. When the string vibrates, two successive harmonics are found to occur at frequencies $750 \mathrm{~Hz}$ and $1000 \mathrm{~Hz}$. What is the value of tension $T$ in Newton?

choices.text:
Solution:
We can use the formula $T = \frac{m \omega^2}{2L}$ to calculate the tension $T$, where $m$ is the mass of the string, $\omega$ is the angular frequency, and $L$ is the length of the string.

The angular frequency $\omega$ is related to the frequency $f$ by the formula $\omega = 2\pi f$.

For the first harmonic, we have $f_1 = 750 \mathrm{~Hz}$ and $\omega_1 = 2\pi \times 750 = 4700\pi \mathrm{~rad/s}$.

For the second harmonic, we have $f_2 = 1000 \mathrm{~Hz}$ and $\omega_2 = 2\pi \times 1000 = 6283\pi \mathrm{~rad/s}$.

Substituting the values into the formula, we get:

$T = \frac{(2 \times 10^{-5} \mathrm{~kg}) \times (4700\pi \mathrm{~rad/s})^2}{2 \times (1 \mathrm{~m})} = 0.0011 \mathrm{~N}$

The value of tension $T$ is 0.0011 N.

When $S_{1}$ and $S_{2}$ have just completed their $3^{\text {rd }}$ and $7^{\text {th }}$ half-lives, respectively, what is the ratio $A_{1} / A_{2}$?

Problem: In a radioactive decay process, the activity is defined as $A=-\frac{d N}{d t}$, where $N(t)$ is the number of radioactive nuclei at time $t$. Two radioactive sources, $S_{1}$ and $S_{2}$ have same activity at time $t=0$. At a later time, the activities of $S_{1}$ and $S_{2}$ are $A_{1}$ and $A_{2}$, respectively. When $S_{1}$ and $S_{2}$ have just completed their $3^{\text {rd }}$ and $7^{\text {th }}$ half-lives, respectively, what is the ratio $A_{1} / A_{2}$?

choices.text:
Solution: The half-life of a radioactive source is the time it takes for the activity of the source to decrease by a factor of two. Therefore, after the 3rd and 7th half-lives, the activities of $S_{1}$ and $S_{2}$ will be $\frac{A_{1}}{2^{3}}$ and $\frac{A_{2}}{2^{7}}$, respectively.

The ratio of the activities of $S_{1}$ and $S_{2}$ after the 3rd and 7th half-lives is then given by:

$\frac{A_{1}}{A_{2}} = \frac{\frac{A_{1}}{2^{3}}}{\frac{A_{2}}{2^{7}}} = \frac{2^{7}A_{1}}{2^{3}A_{2}} = \frac{2^{4}A_{1}}{A_{2}}$

Therefore, the ratio $A_{1} / A_{2}$ after the 3rd and 7th half-lives is $\frac{2^{4}A_{1}}{A_{2}}$.

Final Answer: $\frac{2^{4}A_{1}}{A_{2}}$

If $\mathrm{r}_{\mathrm{z}}=\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2} \mathrm{r}_{\mathrm{y}} ; \mathrm{r}_{\mathrm{y}}=\frac{8}{\sqrt{3}} \mathrm{r}_{\mathrm{x}} ; \mathrm{M}_{\mathrm{z}}=\frac{3}{2} \mathrm{M}_{\mathrm{y}}$ and $\mathrm{M}_{\mathrm{Z}}=3 \mathrm{M}_{\mathrm{x}}$, then the correct statement(s) is(are)



[Given: $M_{x}, M_{y}$, and $M_{z}$ are molar masses of metals $x, y$, and $z$, respectively.



$r_{x}, r_{y}$, and $r_{z}$ are atomic radii of metals $x, y$, and $z$, respectively.]



(A) Packing efficiency of unit cell of $x>$ Packing efficiency of unit cell of $y>$ Packing efficiency of unit cell of $z$



(B) $\mathrm{L}_{\mathrm{y}}>\mathrm{L}_{\mathrm{z}}$



(C) $\mathrm{L}_{\mathrm{x}}>\mathrm{L}_{\mathrm{y}}$



(D) Density of $x>$ Density of $y$
prompt:
In this problem, multiple options can be correct. Give a detailed solution and end the solution with the final answer.

Problem: Atoms of metals $\mathrm{x}, \mathrm{y}$, and $\mathrm{z}$ form face-centred cubic (fcc) unit cell of edge length $\mathrm{L}_{\mathrm{x}}$, body-centred cubic (bcc) unit cell of edge length $\mathrm{L}_{\mathrm{y}}$, and simple cubic unit cell of edge length $\mathrm{L}_{\mathrm{z}}$, respectively.

If $\mathrm{r}_{\mathrm{z}}=\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2} \mathrm{r}_{\mathrm{y}} ; \mathrm{r}_{\mathrm{y}}=\frac{8}{\sqrt{3}} \mathrm{r}_{\mathrm{x}} ; \mathrm{M}_{\mathrm{z}}=\frac{3}{2} \mathrm{M}_{\mathrm{y}}$ and $\mathrm{M}_{\mathrm{Z}}=3 \mathrm{M}_{\mathrm{x}}$, then the correct statement(s) is(are)

[Given: $M_{x}, M_{y}$, and $M_{z}$ are molar masses of metals $x, y$, and $z$, respectively.

$r_{x}, r_{y}$, and $r_{z}$ are atomic radii of metals $x, y$, and $z$, respectively.]

(A) Packing efficiency of unit cell of $x>$ Packing efficiency of unit cell of $y>$ Packing efficiency of unit cell of $z$

(B) $\mathrm{L}_{\mathrm{y}}>\mathrm{L}_{\mathrm{z}}$

(C) $\mathrm{L}_{\mathrm{x}}>\mathrm{L}_{\mathrm{y}}$

(D) Density of $x>$ Density of $y$

choices.text:
Solution:

The packing efficiency of a unit cell is the ratio of the volume of the atoms in the unit cell to the total volume of the unit cell. The packing efficiency of a fcc unit cell is $\frac{\pi}{6} \approx 0.524$, the packing efficiency of a bcc unit cell is $\frac{\pi}{8} \approx 0.393$, and the packing efficiency of a simple cubic unit cell is $\frac{1}{2} \approx 0.5$. Therefore, option (A) is correct.

The edge length of a unit cell is related to the atomic radius of the atom in the unit cell. The edge length of a fcc unit cell is $\frac{4}{\sqrt{3}} \mathrm{r}$, the edge length of a bcc unit cell is $\frac{2}{\sqrt{3}} \mathrm{r}$, and the edge length of a simple cubic unit cell is $\mathrm{r}$. Therefore, using the given information, we can calculate the edge lengths of the unit cells of metals $x, y$, and $z$ as follows:

$\mathrm{L}_{\mathrm{x}}=\frac{4}{\sqrt{3}} \mathrm{r}_{\mathrm{x}}$

$\mathrm{L}_{\mathrm{y}}=\frac{2}{\sqrt{3}} \mathrm{r}_{\mathrm{y}}$

$\mathrm{L}_{\mathrm{z}}=\mathrm{r}_{\mathrm{z}}$

Since $\mathrm{r}_{\mathrm{z}}=\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2} \mathrm{r}_{\mathrm{y}}$ and $\mathrm{r}_{\mathrm{y}}=\frac{8}{\sqrt{3}} \mathrm{r}_{\mathrm{x}}$, we can substitute these values in the above equations to get:

$\mathrm{L}_{\mathrm{x}}=\frac{4}{\sqrt{3}} \mathrm{r}_{\mathrm{x}}$

$\mathrm{L}_{\mathrm{y}}=\frac{2}{\sqrt{3}} \frac{8}{\sqrt{3}} \mathrm{r}_{\mathrm{x}}=16 \mathrm{r}_{\mathrm{x}}$

$\mathrm{L}_{\mathrm{z}}=\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2} \frac{8}{\sqrt{3}} \mathrm{r}_{\mathrm{x}}=4 \mathrm{r}_{\mathrm{x}}$

Therefore, $\mathrm{L}_{\mathrm{y}}>\mathrm{L}_{\mathrm{z}}$, so option (B) is correct.

Similarly, $\mathrm{L}_{\mathrm{x}}>\mathrm{L}_{\mathrm{y}}$, so option (C) is correct.

The density of a metal is the ratio of its molar mass to its volume. The volume of a unit cell is the edge length of the unit cell cubed. Therefore, using the given information, we can calculate the densities of metals $x, y$, and $z$ as follows:

$\mathrm{Density}_{\mathrm{x}}=\frac{\mathrm{M}_{\mathrm{x}}}{\mathrm{L}_{\mathrm{x}}^{3}}=\frac{\mathrm{M}_{\mathrm{x}}}{\left(\frac{4}{\sqrt{3}} \mathrm{r}_{\mathrm{x}}\right)^{3}}$

$\mathrm{Density}_{\mathrm{y}}=\frac{\mathrm{M}_{\mathrm{y}}}{\mathrm{L}_{\mathrm{y}}^{3}}=\frac{\mathrm{M}_{\mathrm{y}}}{\left(16 \mathrm{r}_{\mathrm{x}}\right)^{3}}$

$\mathrm{Density}_{\mathrm{z}}=\frac{\mathrm{M}_{\mathrm{z}}}{\mathrm{L}_{\mathrm{z}}^{3}}=\frac{\mathrm{M}_{\mathrm{z}}}{\left(4 \mathrm{r}_{\mathrm{x}}\right)^{3}}$

Since $\mathrm{M}_{\mathrm{z}}=\frac{3}{2} \mathrm{M}_{\mathrm{y}}$ and $\mathrm{M}_{\mathrm{Z}}=3 \mathrm{M}_{\mathrm{x}}$, we can substitute these values in the above equations to get:

$\mathrm{Density}_{\mathrm{x}}=\frac{\mathrm{M}_{\mathrm{x}}}{\left(\frac{4}{\sqrt{3}} \mathrm{r}_{\mathrm{x}}\right)^{3}}$

$\mathrm{Density}_{\mathrm{y}}=\frac{\frac{3}{2} \mathrm{M}_{\mathrm{x}}}{\left(16 \mathrm{r}_{\mathrm{x}}\right)^{3}}$

$\mathrm{Density}_{\mathrm{z}}=\frac{3 \mathrm{M}_{\mathrm{x}}}{\left(4 \mathrm{r}_{\mathrm{x}}\right)^{3}}$

Therefore, $\mathrm{Density}_{\mathrm{x}}>\mathrm{Density}_{\mathrm{y}}$, so option (D) is correct.

The correct statement(s) is(are): (A), (B), (C), and (D).

Problem: $50 \mathrm{~mL}$ of 0.2 molal urea solution (density $=1.012 \mathrm{~g} \mathrm{~mL}^{-1}$ at $300 \mathrm{~K}$ ) is mixed with $250 \mathrm{~mL}$ of a solution containing $0.06 \mathrm{~g}$ of urea. Both the solutions were prepared in the same solvent. What is the osmotic pressure (in Torr) of the resulting solution at $300 \mathrm{~K}$?

[Use: Molar mass of urea $=60 \mathrm{~g} \mathrm{~mol}^{-1}$; gas constant, $\mathrm{R}=62$ L Torr K${ }^{-1} \mathrm{~mol}^{-1}$;

Assume, $\Delta_{\text {mix }} \mathrm{H}=0, \Delta_{\text {mix }} \mathrm{V}=0$ ]

choices.text:
Solution:

Step 1: Calculate the molarity of the 0.2 molal urea solution.

Molarity $= \frac{\text {Molality}}{\text {Density}}$

$= \frac{0.2 \mathrm{~mol} \mathrm{~kg}^{-1}}{1.012 \mathrm{~g} \mathrm{~mL}^{-1}}$

$= 0.198 \mathrm{~mol} \mathrm{~L}^{-1}$

Step 2: Calculate the moles of urea present in the 0.2 molal urea solution.

Moles of urea $= \text {Molarity} \times \text {Volume}$

$= 0.198 \mathrm{~mol} \mathrm{~L}^{-1} \times 0.05 \mathrm{~L}$

$= 0.0099 \mathrm{~mol}$

Step 3: Calculate the moles of urea present in the solution containing 0.06 g of urea.

Moles of urea $= \frac{\text {Mass of urea}}{\text {Molar mass of urea}}$

$= \frac{0.06 \mathrm{~g}}{60 \mathrm{~g} \mathrm{~mol}^{-1}}$

$= 0.001 \mathrm{~mol}$

Step 4: Calculate the total moles of urea present in the resulting solution.

Total moles of urea $= 0.0099 \mathrm{~mol} + 0.001 \mathrm{~mol}$

$= 0.0109 \mathrm{~mol}$

Step 5: Calculate the osmotic pressure of the resulting solution.

Osmotic pressure $= \frac{n \mathrm{~R} \mathrm{~T}}{V}$

$= \frac{0.0109 \mathrm{~mol} \times 62 \mathrm{~L} \mathrm{~Torr} \mathrm{~K}^{-1} \mathrm{~mol}^{-1} \times 300 \mathrm{~K}}{0.25 \mathrm{~L}}$

$= 7.6 \mathrm{~Torr}$

Therefore, the osmotic pressure of the resulting solution at 300 K is 7.6 Torr.

prompt:

Problem: A trinitro compound, 1,3,5-tris-(4-nitrophenyl)benzene, on complete reaction with an excess of $\mathrm{Sn} / \mathrm{HCl}$ gives a major product, which on treatment with an excess of $\mathrm{NaNO}_{2} / \mathrm{HCl}$ at $0{ }^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ provides $\mathbf{P}$ as the product. $\mathbf{P}$, upon treatment with excess of $\mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{O}$ at room temperature, gives the product $\mathbf{Q}$. Bromination of $\mathbf{Q}$ in aqueous medium furnishes the product $\mathbf{R}$. The compound $\mathbf{P}$ upon treatment with an excess of phenol under basic conditions gives the product $\mathbf{S}$.

The molar mass difference between compounds $\mathbf{Q}$ and $\mathbf{R}$ is $474 \mathrm{~g} \mathrm{~mol}^{-1}$ and between compounds $\mathbf{P}$ and $\mathbf{S}$ is $172.5 \mathrm{~g} \mathrm{~mol}^{-1}$. What is the number of heteroatoms present in one molecule of $\mathbf{R}$?

[Use: Molar mass (in g mol${ }^{-1}$ ): $\mathrm{H}=1, \mathrm{C}=12, \mathrm{~N}=14, \mathrm{O}=16, \mathrm{Br}=80, \mathrm{Cl}=35.5$

Atoms other than $\mathrm{C}$ and $\mathrm{H}$ are considered as heteroatoms]

choices.text:
Solution:
Let the number of heteroatoms present in one molecule of $\mathbf{R}$ be $x$.

The molar mass difference between compounds $\mathbf{Q}$ and $\mathbf{R}$ is $474 \mathrm{~g} \mathrm{~mol}^{-1}$.

Therefore, the difference in the number of heteroatoms between compounds $\mathbf{Q}$ and $\mathbf{R}$ is $\frac{474}{14}=33.86$.

Let the number of heteroatoms present in one molecule of $\mathbf{Q}$ be $y$.

Therefore, the number of heteroatoms present in one molecule of $\mathbf{R}$ is $y+33.86$.

The molar mass difference between compounds $\mathbf{P}$ and $\mathbf{S}$ is $172.5 \mathrm{~g} \mathrm{~mol}^{-1}$.

Therefore, the difference in the number of heteroatoms between compounds $\mathbf{P}$ and $\mathbf{S}$ is $\frac{172.5}{14}=12.32$.

Let the number of heteroatoms present in one molecule of $\mathbf{P}$ be $z$.

Therefore, the number of heteroatoms present in one molecule of $\mathbf{S}$ is $z+12.32$.

Since the number of heteroatoms present in one molecule of $\mathbf{R}$ is $y+33.86$ and the number of heteroatoms present in one molecule of $\mathbf{S}$ is $z+12.32$, the number of heteroatoms present in one molecule of $\mathbf{R}$ is $(y+33.86)-(z+12.32)=y-z+21.54$.

Therefore, the number of heteroatoms present in one molecule of $\mathbf{R}$ is $y-z+21.54$.

Final Answer: The number of heteroatoms present in one molecule of $\mathbf{R}$ is $y-z+21.54$ (correct upto 2 decimal digits).

question:
A trinitro compound, 1,3,5-tris-(4-nitrophenyl)benzene, on complete reaction with an excess of $\mathrm{Sn} / \mathrm{HCl}$ gives a major product, which on treatment with an excess of $\mathrm{NaNO}_{2} / \mathrm{HCl}$ at $0{ }^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ provides $\mathbf{P}$ as the product. $\mathbf{P}$, upon treatment with excess of $\mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{O}$ at room temperature, gives the product $\mathbf{Q}$. Bromination of $\mathbf{Q}$ in aqueous medium furnishes the product $\mathbf{R}$. The compound $\mathbf{P}$ upon treatment with an excess of phenol under basic conditions gives the product $\mathbf{S}$.



The molar mass difference between compounds $\mathbf{Q}$ and $\mathbf{R}$ is $474 \mathrm{~g} \mathrm{~mol}^{-1}$ and between compounds $\mathbf{P}$ and $\mathbf{S}$ is $172.5 \mathrm{~g} \mathrm{~mol}^{-1}$. What is the total number of carbon atoms and heteroatoms present in one molecule of $\mathbf{S}$?



[Use: Molar mass (in $\mathrm{g} \mathrm{mol}^{-1}$ ): $\mathrm{H}=1, \mathrm{C}=12, \mathrm{~N}=14, \mathrm{O}=16, \mathrm{Br}=80, \mathrm{Cl}=35.5$



Atoms other than $\mathrm{C}$ and $\mathrm{H}$ are considered as heteroatoms]
prompt:
In this problem, the final will be a numeric value. Give the numerical answer correct upto the 2nd decimal digit. Give a detailed solution and end the solution with the final answer.

Problem: A trinitro compound, 1,3,5-tris-(4-nitrophenyl)benzene, on complete reaction with an excess of $\mathrm{Sn} / \mathrm{HCl}$ gives a major product, which on treatment with an excess of $\mathrm{NaNO}_{2} / \mathrm{HCl}$ at $0{ }^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ provides $\mathbf{P}$ as the product. $\mathbf{P}$, upon treatment with excess of $\mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{O}$ at room temperature, gives the product $\mathbf{Q}$. Bromination of $\mathbf{Q}$ in aqueous medium furnishes the product $\mathbf{R}$. The compound $\mathbf{P}$ upon treatment with an excess of phenol under basic conditions gives the product $\mathbf{S}$.

The molar mass difference between compounds $\mathbf{Q}$ and $\mathbf{R}$ is $474 \mathrm{~g} \mathrm{~mol}^{-1}$ and between compounds $\mathbf{P}$ and $\mathbf{S}$ is $172.5 \mathrm{~g} \mathrm{~mol}^{-1}$. What is the total number of carbon atoms and heteroatoms present in one molecule of $\mathbf{S}$?

[Use: Molar mass (in $\mathrm{g} \mathrm{mol}^{-1}$ ): $\mathrm{H}=1, \mathrm{C}=12, \mathrm{~N}=14, \mathrm{O}=16, \mathrm{Br}=80, \mathrm{Cl}=35.5$

Atoms other than $\mathrm{C}$ and $\mathrm{H}$ are considered as heteroatoms]

choices.text:
Solution:

Let us denote the total number of carbon atoms and heteroatoms present in one molecule of $\mathbf{S}$ as $x$ and $y$ respectively.

We know that the molar mass difference between compounds $\mathbf{Q}$ and $\mathbf{R}$ is $474 \mathrm{~g} \mathrm{~mol}^{-1}$ and between compounds $\mathbf{P}$ and $\mathbf{S}$ is $172.5 \mathrm{~g} \mathrm{~mol}^{-1}$.

Therefore,

$\begin{align} & \text {Molar mass of } \mathbf{Q}-\text {Molar mass of } \mathbf{R} \\ &=474 \mathrm{~g} \mathrm{~mol}^{-1} \\ & \Rightarrow \text {Molar mass of } \mathbf{Q}=474+\text {Molar mass of } \mathbf{R} \end{align}$

and

$\begin{align} & \text {Molar mass of } \mathbf{P}-\text {Molar mass of } \mathbf{S} \\ &=172.5 \mathrm{~g} \mathrm{~mol}^{-1} \\ & \Rightarrow \text {Molar mass of } \mathbf{P}=172.5+\text {Molar mass of } \mathbf{S} \end{align}$

Now,

$\begin{align} & \text {Molar mass of } \mathbf{Q}-\text {Molar mass of } \mathbf{P} \\ &=\left(474+\text {Molar mass of } \mathbf{R}\right)-\left(172.5+\text {Molar mass of } \mathbf{S}\right) \\ &=474-172.5 \\ &=301.5 \mathrm{~g} \mathrm{~mol}^{-1} \end{align}$

Therefore,

$\begin{align} & \text {Molar mass of } \mathbf{Q}-\text {Molar mass of } \mathbf{P} \\ &=301.5 \mathrm{~g} \mathrm{~mol}^{-1} \\ & \Rightarrow \text {Molar mass of } \mathbf{Q}=301.5+\text {Molar mass of } \mathbf{P} \end{align}$

Now,

$\begin{align} & \text {Molar mass of } \mathbf{Q}=x \times 12+y \times \left(14+16+80+35.5\right)+\text {Molar mass of } \mathbf{P} \\ &=x \times 12+y \times 155.5+172.5 \end{align}$

Therefore,

$\begin{align} & x \times 12+y \times 155.5+172.5=301.5+172.5 \\ & \Rightarrow x \times 12+y \times 155.5=129 \end{align}$

On solving the above equation, we get

$x=10$ and $y=3$

Therefore, the total number of carbon atoms and heteroatoms present in one molecule of $\mathbf{S}$ is 10 and 3 respectively.

Final Answer: The total number of carbon atoms and heteroatoms present in one molecule of $\mathbf{S}$ is 10 and 3 respectively.
